case_name: Raja of Puri v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 135 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 135 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1958, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 321 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated April 30, 1958 of Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 321 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1958, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 321 of 1955. C. Setalvad, Sarjoo Prasad and A. D. Mathur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Writ petition filed in Orissa High Court by father of present appellant challenging constitutionality of Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The challenge to the Act was made by the father of the present appellant by a writ petition filed in the High Court of Orissa. The appellant was substituted for his father on the death of the latter while the writ petition was pending in the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant substituted for his father upon father's death while writ petition pending in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was substituted for his father on the death of the latter while the writ petition was pending in the High Court. The case put forward in the petition firstly was that the Shri Jagannath Temple  hereinafter referred to as the Temple  was the private property of the petitioner, Raja of Puri

facts.text: Petitioner claimed Shri Jagannath Temple was private property of Raja of Puri.

anchor.surface_text: The case put forward in the petition firstly was that the Shri Jagannath Temple  hereinafter referred to as the Temple  was the private property of the petitioner, Raja of Puri, and the Act, which deprived the appellant of his property was unconstitutional in view of Art. 19 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner alternatively claimed sole right of superintendence and management of Temple, taken away without compensation, violating Art. 31.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative it was submitted that the appellant had the sole right of superintendence and management of the Temple and that that right companyld number be taken away without payment of companypensation, and the Act inasmuch as it took away that right without any companypensation was hit by Art. 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: State claimed Temple is public temple, not private property of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was opposed on behalf of the State and it was urged that the Temple was number the private property of the appellant. The case of the State was that it was a public temple and the State always had the right to see that it was properly administered.

facts.text: Before British conquered Orissa in 1803, Temple managed by Muslim rulers directly through Hindu employees.

anchor.surface_text: Before the British companyquered Orissa in 1803, the Temple had for a long time been managed by Muslim Rulers directly, though through Hindu employees.

facts.text: After 1803, Temple managed directly by British Government, then by Regulation IV of 1809 made over to Raja of Khurda (Raja of Puri) as hereditary superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: After 1803, the Temple began to be managed directly by the British Government, though by Regulation IV of 1809 the management was made over to the Raja of Khurda  who is number known as the Raja of Puri , who was appointed as hereditary superintendent in view of his familys companynection in the past with the Temple.

facts.text: Government intervened in Temple management multiple times due to mismanagement over last century and a half, administering secular affairs directly.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, whenever there was mismanagement in the Temple during the companyrse of the last century and a half, the Government always intervened and many a time administered the secular affairs of the Temple directly through one of its officers in whose favour the then Raja was made to execute a power of attorney divesting himself companypletely of all powers of management.

facts.text: Puri Shri Jagannath Temple Administration Act, No. XIV of 1952 passed for appointment of Special Officer to prepare record of rights and duties.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the State further was that in view of the reported mismanagement of the Temple, the State legislature passed the Puri Shri Jagannath Temple  Administration  Act,  No. XIV of 1952  for the appointment of a Special Officer for the preparation of a record pertaining to the rights and duties of different sevaks and pujaris

facts.text: Special Officer submitted report on March 15, 1954 disclosing serious mismanagement.

anchor.surface_text: A Special Officer was accordingly appointed who submitted his report on March 15, 1954, which disclosed serious mismanagement of the affairs of the Temple and in companysequence the Act was passed in 1955.

facts.text: Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954 (No. 11 of 1955) passed in 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and in companysequence the Act was passed in 1955. The State companytended that the Act was perfectly valid and companystitutional and did number offend any companystitutional provision.

facts.text: In High Court, appellant conceded Temple is public temple, properties of deity, not private of Raja.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came to be argued before the High Court, the appellant gave up the plea that the Temple was his private property and it was companyceded that it was a public temple, the properties of which were the properties of the deity and number the private properties of the Raja of Puri.

facts.text: Raja of Puri has two-fold connection: adya sevak (chief servant) with rights/privileges, and sole superintendent of secular affairs.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Raja of Puri had two-fold companynection with the Temple. In the first place, the Raja is the adya sevak, i.e., the chief servant of the Temple and in that capacity he has certain rights and privileges. In addition to that, he was the sole superintendent of the Temple

facts.text: Orissa High Court upheld Act as constitutional except s.28(2)(f), struck down that provision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled all the submissions ,on behalf of the appellant and held that the Act was valid and companystitutional except for one provision companytained in s. 28 2  f  thereof. The High Court therefore struck down that provision and upheld the companystitutionality of the rest of the Act.

facts.text: Orissa High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant applied for a certificate which was granted and that is how the appeal has companye up before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 5, 1964 by Wanchoo J.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupta, Additional Solicitor-General, M. S. K. Sastri and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondent. March 5, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- WANCHOO, J.--This appeal on a certificate granted by the Orissa High Court

facts.text: Temple is unique institution in Orissa, class by itself, national importance, no comparable temple.

anchor.surface_text: As to that the affidavit on behalf of the State Government is that the Temple is a unique institution in the State of Orissa and is in a class by itself and that there is numbercomparison between the Temple and other temples in the State.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Temple stands in class by itself requiring special treatment, not discriminatory under Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt after this averment on behalf of the State that the Temple occupies a unique position in the State of Orissa and is a temple of national importance and numberother temple in that State can companypare with it stands in a class by itself

facts.text: Act provides for management of secular affairs of Temple, does not interfere with religious affairs per record of rights or custom.

anchor.surface_text: This review of the provisions of the Act shows that broadly speaking the Act provides for the management of the secular affairs of the Temple and does number interfere, with the religious affairs thereof, which have to be performed according to the record of rights

facts.text: Raja's rights as adya sevak untouched by Act; only sole management of secular affairs replaced by committee with Raja as chairman.

anchor.surface_text: The Act has only deprived him of the second right i.e., the sole management of the Temple which carried numberbeneficial enjoyment of any property with it and has companyferred that management on a companymittee of which he still remains the chairman.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected challenge under Art.19(1)(f) and Art.31(2) to removal of sole superintendence.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the companystitutionality of the Act on the ground that the sole right of superintendence has been taken away from the appellant and that is hit by Art. 19 1  f  or Art. 31 2  must therefore fail.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Act does not take away rights of appellant as adya sevak.

anchor.surface_text: Now we have already referred to the provisions of the Act, and if one looks at those provisions one finds numberhing in them which takes away the rights of the appellant as adya sevak.

facts.text: Section 8 of Act preserves Raja's rights and privileges as adya sevak in respect of Gajapati Maharaja Seva.

holdings.text: The Act cannot be struck down under Art. 14 because the Temple holds a unique position amongst the Hindu temples in the State of Orissa and no other temple can be regarded as comparable with it.

anchor.surface_text: The same reasons in our opinion apply to the Temple in the present case and the Act cannot be struck down under Art. 14 because the Temple in the present case holds a unique position amongst the Hindu temples in the State of Orissa and no other temple can be regarded as comparable with it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temple is unique institution of national importance with vast assets and pilgrims from all India, forming separate class justifying special legislation; analogous to Nathdwara temple precedent.

holdings.text: The attack on the constitutionality of the Act on the ground that the sole right of superintendence has been taken away from the appellant and that is hit by Art. 19(1)(f) or Art. 31(2) must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the constitutionality of the Act on the ground that the sole right of superintendence has been taken away from the appellant and that is hit by Art. 19(1)(f) or Art. 31(2) must therefore fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right of superintendence not property carrying beneficial enjoyment; no acquisition by State, merely replacement of sole manager by committee; follows Nathdwara precedent.

holdings.text: The Act does not take away the rights of the appellant as adya sevak; those rights remain intact and are preserved by s.8 and other provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Now we have already referred to the provisions of the Act, and if one looks at those provisions one finds nothing in them which takes away the rights of the appellant as adya sevak.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading shows no express removal; s.8 preserves Gajapati Maharaja Seva rights; other sections like 21(2)(f),(g) presuppose sevak rights intact; distinction between secular management and religious sevak rights.

holdings.text: Clause (1) of s.15 does not interfere with religious affairs; attack thereon fails.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on this provision that it interferes with the religious affairs of the Temple must therefore fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Imposes secular duty on committee to provide materials and ensure performance per record of rights; religious performance by entitled sevaks untouched.

holdings.text: Argument under Art.26(d), 27, 28 rejected as not properly pleaded; no violation found.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No denomination identified in petition; claim based on private ownership, not denominational rights; management remains with Hindus.

holdings.text: Sections 5,6,11,19,21,21A,30 valid as integral to secular management transfer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary for committee's functioning and day-to-day secular administration; no impact on religious affairs.

holdings.text: s.30A validity not decided; to be considered if prosecution arises.

precedents.citation: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan 1

anchor.surface_text: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan 1  where in relation to the temple at Nathdwara with respect to which a special Act had been passed by the State of Rajasthan, this Court observed that a law may be constitutional even though it relates to a single individual if, on account of some special circumstances or reasons applicable to him and number applicable to others, that single individual may be treated as a class by himself.

precedents.case_name: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: a law may be constitutional even though it relates to a single individual if, on account of some special circumstances or reasons applicable to him and number applicable to others, that single individual may be treated as a class by himself; temple had unique position amongst Hindu Shrines and no temple comparable with it

anchor.surface_text: Tilkayat Govindlaljis case 1 . If anything, the case of the appellant is weaker than that of Shri Govindlalji, for the appellant in the present case was conferred with the power of superintendence by Regulation IV of 1809 after the British conquered Orissa.

precedents.case_name: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: complete parallel between the provisions of the Act and the Act relating to the temple at Nathdwara

anchor.surface_text: Tilkayat Govindlaljis case.  1 , all that has happened in the present case is that the sole right of the appellant to  1 1964 1 S.C.R. 561. manage the property has been extinguished and in its place another body for the purpose of the administration of the property of the Temple has been created.

precedents.case_name: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: the sole right to manage the property has been extinguished and another body created; office of one functionary brought to an end and another created; such process does not constitute acquisition
precedents.cited_holding: extinguishing an office of management and creating a new body does not amount to acquisition of property under Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: Tilkayat Govindlaljis case 1 . As we have already pointed out, the appellant and his predecessors always had two distinct rights with respect to this Temple.

precedents.case_name: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: such a process cannot be said to constitute the acquisition of the extinguished office or the vesting of the rights in the person holding that office

anchor.surface_text: 1 1964 1 S.C.R. 561. and serious irregularities thereafter the Government had to intervene on various occasions in the past.

precedents.case_name: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan

outcome.relief_summary: All constitutional challenges to the Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954 rejected; Act upheld as valid and constitutional

anchor.surface_text: The same reasons in our opinion apply to the Temple in the present case and the Act cannot be struck down under Art. 14 because the Temple in the present case holds a unique position amongst the Hindu temples in the State of Orissa and no other temple can be regarded as comparable with it.
